title: 109_hr5806
content:
The Act is titled the "Communities of Color Teen Pregnancy Prevention Act of 2006". It focuses on community-based intervention programs. The "Communities of Color Teen Pregnancy Prevention Act of 2006" authorizes grants to public and nonprofit entities for projects aimed at preventing teen pregnancies in minority or immigrant communities with high rates of teen pregnancy. Recipients must agree to promote effective communication within families about preventing teen pregnancy. The "Communities of Color Teen Pregnancy Prevention Act of 2006" authorizes grants to public and nonprofit entities for projects aimed at preventing teen pregnancies in minority or immigrant communities with high rates of teen pregnancy. Recipients must educate community members about the consequences of teen pregnancy, encourage young people to postpone sexual activity, provide contraceptive information for sexually active youth, and inform them about the responsibilities and consequences of parenthood. Grants are given to applicants who agree to utilize effective strategies in carrying out the prevention purpose. The applicant for grants under the "Communities of Color Teen Pregnancy Prevention Act of 2006" must use effective strategies in their projects. They must submit a report to the Secretary detailing project outcomes, and evaluations of six projects must be conducted within 12 months to assess how activities increased education and awareness on teen pregnancy prevention. Authorization of $40,000,000 for teen pregnancy prevention services annually from 2007 to 2011. SEC. 3. SCHOOL-BASED PROJECTS. The Secretary may grant funds to public and nonprofit entities to establish projects in eligible communities with public schools to prevent teen pregnancy, provide support services, health and educational services, promote better outcomes for pregnant teens, and train individuals for school-based programs. The Secretary prioritizes grants for projects in eligible communities to prevent teen pregnancy. Grants require forming a coalition including public schools and service providers. Funds can be used for training individuals. $10,000,000 is authorized annually for 2007-2011. SEC. 4. MULTIMEDIA CAMPAIGNS. The Secretary will provide grants to public and nonprofit entities for multimedia campaigns on teen pregnancy awareness. Priority will be given to campaigns targeting eligible communities. Grants require information on teen pregnancy prevention and identifying relevant organizations. The Secretary will provide grants for teen pregnancy prevention campaigns, prioritizing eligible communities. $6,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007-2011. SEC. 5. NATIONAL CLEARINGHOUSE. The Secretary will provide grants to a nonprofit entity to establish a National Clearinghouse for Teen Pregnancy Prevention. The Clearinghouse aims to offer information and assistance to various entities to develop content addressing teen pregnancy and to support parents in preventing teen pregnancy by enhancing communication with their children about sex and relationships. The grant requirements for organizations focusing on preventing teen pregnancy include being nationally recognized, nonpartisan, having at least 10 years of experience, and the ability to work with diverse groups to reduce teen pregnancy rates. The organization must be nationally recognized, nonpartisan, have at least 10 years of experience, and work with diverse groups to reduce teen pregnancy rates. They should have experience in culturally competent methods, research, scientific analyses, evaluations, and prevention strategies. $1,500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2011 for this purpose. SEC. 6. RESEARCH. The Secretary will provide grants for research on teen pregnancy prevention in eligible communities, focusing on factors contributing to high rates. Research will investigate teen pregnancy incidence, impact on health, well-being, and scholastic achievement of teenagers in these communities. Teen pregnancy rates vary by location, population subgroup, and level of acculturation. The physical and social environment play a role in increasing rates of teen pregnancy. Aspirations also affect young women's risk of teen pregnancy. Measures are developed to address race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, environment, and education. The Secretary prioritizes grants for research on teen pregnancy rates, focusing on socioeconomic status, environment, and education. Interdisciplinary approaches and community-based participatory research are emphasized. $7,500,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007-2011. SEC. 7. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.

- Grants under this Act require medically accurate, age-appropriate, and scientifically based information.
- Information, activities, and services must be culturally appropriate for specific population groups.
- Grant applications must be submitted to the Secretary with necessary agreements and information.

SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "eligible community" refers to communities defined in section 2(a), "racial or ethnic minority or immigrant communities" are those with a significant number of minority or immigrant residents, and "Secretary" is defined in section 2(a).
